body: How fast do you tap? There's no difference between touchpad and mouse from the Wayland protocol point of view, so it's a matter of speed when it comes to touchpad double tap.

That's could be related to #6983. 
I tried to check this behavior on my machine, something is weird and it's going on. But I am starting to think this is GNOME 44...
### What I mean ###
While double-tapping did not work for me, double-_clicking_ did. (and tripple-tapping to)
My speed is somewhere around 125~300ms on average.(7.78 in a second) So it should be plenty.
Double-tapping transforms cursor to move alacritty window. Same can be done with _one_ click.

### System ###
OS: Ubuntu 23.04 (Lunar Lobster)
Version: alacritty 0.12.1
Linux/BSD: Wayland with GNOME 44

### Window ###
Default config.
Could someone try the latest master?

With the latest db903503df024a3f5066937fbe0272be88226738 I cannot maximize/unmaximize with touchapd at all. Even with triple tap. Previous 09c4471b4cd6b32a2de79a08c447284b62a80d54 allowed to do it at least with triple tap.
Could you post `WAYLAND_DEBUG=1 alacritty` from it please, as in while doing reproduction steps?
I've tried with my laptop on sway and it works as it should (I see the request to get the window maximized at least) after pressing on the title bar twice.

Log with WAYLAND_DEBUG=1. Double tap and triple tap.

[wl-alacritty.log](https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/files/12021531/wl-alacritty.log)

@darkblaze69 could you please post the `libinput debug-events` (requires root)? It could be the issue in your compositor(mutter) or libinput itself? Just run alacritty instance invoke that command inside of it and start tapping on the status bar (3 times or more). And also collect the `WAYLAND_DEBUG=1` log from the alacritty during it (don't truncate anything, like you did with the previous log).


Also, could you try taping on maximize button?

Besides, the particular path doesn't rely on release events, however the time between the presses were **380ms** according to your log, however our threshold is **300ms**. Could you try pressing really fast? Maybe your touchpad is just really slow, because 300ms is the default in a lot of applications for that...
@darkblaze69 I'd also assume that double click to select a word in alacritty doesn't work for you?

issue.title: Raise double click threshold to 400ms
issue.body:
This should improve the situation with some touchpads. GTK4 is also using the same value.

--

In the issue #7011 the time between the clicks is 370ms if you look into the wayland debug logs, so I guess on some systems it's too tight?

body:
You could try applying this to see if this improves the situation.

```diff
diff --git a/Cargo.lock b/Cargo.lock
index b45e2414..99524298 100644
--- a/Cargo.lock
+++ b/Cargo.lock
@@ -1649,8 +1649,7 @@ checksum = "d29ab0c6d3fc0ee92fe66e2d99f700eab17a8d57d1c1d3b748380fb20baa78cd"
 [[package]]
 name = "sctk-adwaita"
 version = "0.6.0"
-source = "registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index"
-checksum = "2704a44480b79e10d2185d1d246e86b02e177e33bdaaaab3b1f65fdf13771448"
+source = "git+https://github.com/kchibisov/sctk-adwaita?branch=double-click-threshold#5b951d695346e0e64a7fa7c17e691d29a5511187"
 dependencies = [
  "crossfont",
  "log",
diff --git a/Cargo.toml b/Cargo.toml
index efe3cc33..197e1d65 100644
--- a/Cargo.toml
+++ b/Cargo.toml
@@ -11,3 +11,6 @@ resolver = "2"
 lto = "thin"
 debug = 1
 incremental = false
+
+[patch.crates-io]
+sctk-adwaita = { git = "https://github.com/kchibisov/sctk-adwaita", branch = "double-click-threshold" }
```

With this patch I'm able to triple tap again.
I'm sure I'm not slow with taps and doing this pretty fast and it's for sure not the 0.3 of the second. Will run debug events later.
At first I asked in mutter issue tracker and they say it's the client. https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/issues/2669

@darkblaze69 yeah, your issue is the threshold. Maybe your touchpad sends events with a massive delay not related to you? Also, are you running `release` builds? `cargo run --release` at the very least.

I've got the timing information from the `WAYLAND_DEBUG` log, so the events had the said timeout. The patch I've linked made timeout up to 400ms.
double click to select the word works. Guys at mutter say the issue could be something related to CSD.

I've built without the patch with `cargo build --release`, run from `target/release/`
Here's logs:

[li-events.log](https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/files/12032289/li-events.log)

[wl-debug.log](https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/files/12032290/wl-debug.log)

Let's start with the libinput logs This should account for end, but in the `li-events.log` the ind is within 20-30ms, so it doesn't matter, since it's still in 250ms ranges.
```
-event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +0.215s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +1.368s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +1.531s	1 // Double tap here
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +2.613s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +2.798s	1 // Double tap here
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +3.823s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +4.008s	1 // Double tap here
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +4.200s	1 // Triple tap
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +5.403s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +5.588s	1 // Double tap
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +5.766s	1 // Triple tap
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +6.911s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +7.111s	1 // Double tap
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +7.289s	1 // Triple tap
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +10.214s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +11.132s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +12.754s	1
 event11  GESTURE_HOLD_BEGIN      +13.651s	1
```

For me it looks more or less good, however let's now see what we've got on the wayland side, for grep 'wl_pointer@20.button|move|maximize`.

```
[1135579.263] wl_pointer@20.button(2744, 907047, 272, 1)
[1135579.328]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2744)
[1144375.881] wl_pointer@20.button(2761, 915854, 272, 1)
[1144375.918]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2761)
[1145720.100] wl_pointer@20.button(2768, 917182, 272, 1)
[1145720.135]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2768)
[1146965.425] wl_pointer@20.button(2775, 918427, 272, 1)
[1146965.460]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2775)
[1148190.285] wl_pointer@20.button(2782, 919637, 272, 1)
[1148190.320]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2782)
[1148588.580] wl_pointer@20.button(2787, 920014, 272, 1)
[1148588.621]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2787)
[1149762.438] wl_pointer@20.button(2794, 921217, 272, 1)
[1149762.479]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2794)
[1150146.699] wl_pointer@20.button(2799, 921580, 272, 1)
[1150146.769]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2799)
[1151278.781] wl_pointer@20.button(2806, 922725, 272, 1)
[1151278.814]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2806)
[1151641.759] wl_pointer@20.button(2811, 923102, 272, 1)
[1151641.847]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.move(wl_seat@8, 2811)
[1154566.434] wl_pointer@20.button(2828, 926028, 272, 1)
[1154746.590] wl_pointer@20.button(2829, 926084, 272, 0)
[1154746.642]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.set_maximized()
[1157114.567] wl_pointer@20.button(2850, 928568, 272, 1)
[1157293.811] wl_pointer@20.button(2851, 928631, 272, 0)
[1157293.859]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.unset_maximized()
```

We're interested in `wl_pointer@20.button` events, where they hava `1` at the end, the `1` means pressed. The second argument here is a timestamp of the events with milliseconds granularity, so by doing a `diff` between the ones adjustment ones we'll get the time between you've clicked. I'd say before that we don't rely on such a thing internally and we just use the current timestamp when we've seen event during event processing. But let's just compute the differences in time between those events.

```
[1135579.263] wl_pointer@20.button(2744, 907047, 272, 1)
[1144375.881] wl_pointer@20.button(2761, 915854, 272, 1) // 8 seconds 
[1145720.100] wl_pointer@20.button(2768, 917182, 272, 1) // 1328ms 
[1146965.425] wl_pointer@20.button(2775, 918427, 272, 1) // 1245ms
[1148190.285] wl_pointer@20.button(2782, 919637, 272, 1) // 1210 ms
[1148588.580] wl_pointer@20.button(2787, 920014, 272, 1) // 377ms double click
[1149762.438] wl_pointer@20.button(2794, 921217, 272, 1) // 1203ms
[1150146.699] wl_pointer@20.button(2799, 921580, 272, 1) // 363ms double click
[1151278.781] wl_pointer@20.button(2806, 922725, 272, 1) // 1145
[1151641.759] wl_pointer@20.button(2811, 923102, 272, 1) // 377 ms , double click
[1154566.434] wl_pointer@20.button(2828, 926028, 272, 1) // 3s
[1154746.642]  -> xdg_toplevel@35.set_maximized()
```

If you see on the wayland logs, the time between the clicks when you did double clicks were very close to 400ms. On libinput logs the time between the clicks were 150ms-200ms, this is for example what I have in wayland logs on sway and it matches libinput results on my end.

For now though, I'll try to rewrite and use the timestamps directly from the events, since they might provide better results. I'll come back to you with that eventually.

@darkblaze69 do you have any GNOME extensions installed? Or maybe some extra software for touchpad/keyboard which might slow down gnome processing here? It's really odd that your libinput clicks were twice as fast as the ones on the wayland protocol messages dump.
For capturing I've disabled extensions, and I also tried booting from the fresh Arch installation.
Well, I'll try to use timestamps directly and ask you to retest once everything will be in place, but I'm not sure how I could help you further after that.
